i'd like to get a concensus if possible on the definition of God that can be agreed on by all or at least most people that believe in God. surely, one must know what God is if they believe he is.
 
 as you can see, i'm trying to get a theistic definition. i reckon that at least some of these definitions are shared by almost all theists, but feel free to add.

Sorry, I picked 5 before realizing I should only pick 3. But these 5 describe God well to me. The 1 is my vote because no one else has voted yet, and the 100% confirms that it is unanimous so far.
 the perfect, omnipotent, omniscient originator and ruler of the universe 1- 100.00% 
 the principal object of faith and worship in monotheistic religions 0 0% 
 an entity that is above and beyond the universe 0 0% 
 a supreme being according to some particular conception 0 0% 
 the greatest being possible 1- 100.00% 
 the indescribable, uncreated, self existent, eternal all knowing source of all reality and being 1- 100.00% 
 the absolute authority of morality and justice 1- 100.00% 
 any supernatural being worshipped as controlling some part of the world or some aspect of life 0 0% 
 a monotheistic concept of a Supreme Being that is unlike any other being 0 0% 
 the personification of perfection 1- 100.00%
Where's the option for 'Anyone/thing that can kick my XXX?'

God is.
 
 Or, God is not.
God is the personification of ignorance and hubris.

God is what believers say God is. 
 In that their is no other source of information other than the believer, how could it be anything else?

Undefinable (ignore the contradiction). 
 
 Hence why God can never be disproved.

Undefinable (ignore the contradiction). 
 
 Hence why God can never be disproved.

 
 Likewise, God cannot be proved.

ok, it seems as though all voters agree that all the definitions suit god. 
 
 god: the perfect, omnipotent, omniscient originator and ruler of the universe. perfect is a quality that doesnt exist just as infinity is a quantity that doesnt exist. god per this definition doesnt exist
 
 god: the principal object of faith and worship in monotheistic religions. most monotheistic religions have a principal object of faith and worship. such an object can be valid even if it is imagined. god per this definition exists
 
 god: an entity that is above and beyond the universe. the universe envelops everything that exists, as well as theoretical dimensions that may not even exist. there is no such thing as "beyond and above the universe". god per this definition does not exist
 
 god: a supreme being according to some particular conception. i dont even think i need to elaborate on this. god per this definition exists
 
 god: the greatest being possible. this requires a definition of "possible". the common definition suggests that, for example, travelling faster than the speed of light is not possible. therefore god could not travel faster than the speed of light per this definition. this definition has been discussed before, and the conclusion was that god per this definition exists
 
 god: the indescribable, uncreated, self existent, eternal all knowing source of all reality and being. and indescrible entity cannot exist. describling god as indescribable creates a logical absurdity, so god per this definition doesnt exist
 
 god: the absolute authority of morality and justice. morality is clearly based on individual perspective, and no absolute authority dictates what is moral to everybody. god per this definition doesnt exist
 
 its late. i'll work on the rest later

Huh???
 Calling on Athiests to behave like Christians...
 Come again?

 
 Most atheists I know behave much better than Christians, I agree.

To cut a long story short, the consensus is that there is no consensus.
 When applied in a general sence including polytheistic groups "god" means something worshiped. That could be similar to the monotheistic concept(s) or like Vulcan, god of the forge applied to that which may be considered human skill and artefact by rational thinkers.
 The monotheistic concept is, was and always will be a vague thing because if they define it, it becomes testable.
